Description: Large crescentic axe-head: with 12 binding-holes, four in each tang. The cutting edge and butt have been damaged by corrosion. There is considerable surface pitting and the blade is cracked through at one point. The accompanying haft consists of a cylindrical length of wood, now cracked and warped, containing three narrow sockets for the tangs. The haft is enclosed by a tubular metal casing which is in a poor state of preservation. The bottom of the haft was cut and shaped into a peg, now broken, possibly for insertion into a detachable grip.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: Y. Yadin, ‘The Art of Warfare in Biblical Lands’ I (New York, London & Toronto, 1963) I, 168 (Where the haft is shown erroneously attached to a different axe (1899,1016.1217)); E. Kühnert-Eggesbrecht, ‘Die Axt als Waffe und Werkzeug im alten Ägypten’ (Berlin, 1969), 100, C-III/2, pl. VII, 2.
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (94)
Condition: broken into two pieces, the casing of the haft is becoming detatched
Acquisition name: Purchased from: R J Moss & Co
